313.1 Identity and Integrity (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 45, Updated)
description: The stories of Esther and Daniel invite  a dramatic question: “What would you die for?” Dramatic stories and questions aside, the truth is that we answer this question every moment of every day. With each thought and decision we answer the questions, “What do we live for?” “What do we invest in?”

title: 313.2 Identity and Integrity (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 45, Sunday School)
313.3 Identity and Integrity (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 45, Study Notes)
314.1 Kingdom of God on Earth (OT Gospel Doctrine Lessons 46-48, Updated)
314.2 Dominion of God (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 46, Sunday School)
314.3 Dominion of God (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 46, Study Notes)
description: Daniel interprets the vision of the stone cut out of a mountain without hands, but what does the stone mean, exactly? Is it the gospel? The Kingdom of God? The LDS Church? Is there a difference between these terms? This portion discusses Daniel’s vision in literary and historical perspective and continues to explore our role in healing our lives and world.

title: 315.2 Action and Investment (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 47, Sunday School)
315.3 Action and Investment (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 47, Study Notes)
description: We don’t talk about this section of the Jewish Scriptures much–we have no primary songs about Ezra and Nehemiah’s contributions to rebuilding the temple after the Babylonian Exile. these events and the examples of Ezra and Nehemiah prompt discussion of remaining constructive and dealing with difference and opposition.

title: 316.2 Triumph of God (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 48, Sunday School)
316.3 Triumph of God (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 48, Study Notes)
317.1: Come, Follow Me (NT Lesson 1)
description: Welcome to the new curriculum! This introductory podcast

title: 317.2: Introduction to the New Testament
description: I reissued this introductory episode to provide additional perspective on studying the New Testament from both devotional and academic approaches.

title: 318: January 13, 20; Jesus’ Birth (New Testament Weeks 2-3)
description: Christmas comes a bit late! This first episode where we actually get into the New Testament covers the first two chapters of Matthew and Luke. I review the new, more devotional/ministry focused format of the episode, and focus the lesson on what we learn from members of Jesus’ family.

title: 319: Jan 27; Feb 3; Jesus’ Ministry Begins (New Testament Weeks 4-5)
description: What are the first steps toward our vocation? Baptism reminds us that we can become new versions of ourselves, new versions that better align with that self that can improve the world. As we follow Jesus’ example, we invite others to “come and see” and bring the Kingdom near.

title: 320: Feb 10, 17; Temptation and Vocation (New Testament Weeks 6-7)
description: If we have not faced our darkness, we are not good…merely fortunate. The account of Jesus’ temptations in the wilderness masterfully teach us to use our strengths to manage appetite, ego, and greed. We also learn the best way to manage temptation… to devote ourselves to the good we can do in the world.

title: 321: Feb 24; Inner Law and Integrity (New Testament Week 8)
description: Jesus’ teachings get at the heart of the gospel: Be good. Be happy. Be whole. The tricky thing is, we humans are terrible at predicting what will make us happy and well, which is why it is so important to internalize the principles of the gospel. We become good as we practice goodness. When that goodness becomes who we are, we can’t lose.

title: 322: March 3; Live Well Today (New Testament Week 9)
description: My name is Jared, and I’m a recovering idealist. Anyone else? I used to waste so much energy being anxious. Well, Jesus said not to.

title: 323: March 10; Healing Ministry (New Testament Week 10)
description: What is religion for? What are people for?

title: 324: March 17; Bring the Kingdom Near (New Testament Week 11)
description: Jesus told the apostles to preach that the kingdom of God was near…  and then make that happen with their deeds. And as always, Jesus warns that we must live  the word rather than merely think ourselves righteous.

title: 325: March 24; Cycles of Virtue and Vice (New Testament Week 12)
description: Jesus teaches about priorities and virtuous and vicious cycles. In other  words, if we make good use of what we have we will gain more; if we  make poor use of what we have we will lose “even what we seem to have”  (Luke

title: 326: March 31; Bread of Life (New Testament Week 13)
description: Jesus teaches that greater than the miracle of feeding the multitudes or  even healing the body is feeding and healing the soul. And one key to  feeding the soul is to nurture our personal relationship with the Bread  of Life.

title: 327: April 14; Transfiguration (New Testament Week 15)
description: What would we think of ourselves transfigured? Are we prepared for the  effort and pain that experiencing our better selves would require? These  chapters teach us about cooperating with those who have common goals,  transformation, and ask the provocative question: What are we purchasing  with the currency of our soul?  This episode follows the Come Follow Me Home Study week for April 14.

title: 328: April 21; Easter (New Testament Week 16)
description: I think the most significant thing about Holy Week is that it fosters a holistic approach to Easter. It is not cheap celebration; it is full priced, high cost joy. It does not just celebrate life. It celebrates new, glorious, unexpected life after the agony of disappointment, betrayal, loss, rejection, and the death of everything we know.

title: 329: Atoning Human Nature (Bonus Episode)
description: The idea that we humans are “enemies to God” is disturbing, but the deeper and equally troubling truth is that we are mostly just disappointing. Paradoxically, it is by fully acknowledging our humanness that we redeem it through humble orientation toward grace, God, and goodness.

title: 330: Holy Week, by Carol Lynn Pearson (Bonus Episode)
description: In this bonus episode I read Carol Lynn Pearson’s Easter short story, “Holy Week”. I hope you find it as moving as I did.

title: 331: April 28; May 5; Insiders and Outsiders (New Testament Weeks 17-18)
description: In these chapters we have shepherds going to rescue the lost sheep, and a  Priest and Levite who avoid the potentially dead man. In John, Jesus  declares himself the water of life, the light of the world, and the Good  Shepherd. Taken together, Jesus’ teachings challenge our  insider/outsider tribal thinking.

title: 333: May 19: Was Jesus Married? (New Testament Week 20)
description: Most of our stories have to do with relationships, usually relationships that end “happily ever after”. In reality, marriage is much more complicated! This episode explores the idea, ideal, and history of marriage, as well as what makes a good marriage on earth as it is in heaven. And yes, I have a compelling answer to the question of whether Jesus was married.

title: 334: May 26; Be What You Seem (New Testament Week 21)
description: Jesus’ protest in the temple got him killed. In these chapters we see him as the powerful Messiah, coming into the seat of power triumphant yet humble and then standing up to corruption in the holiest most powerful institution of his day. These powerful actions drive home Jesus’ teachings that we should align our principles and practices, and live in such a way that we can peacefully explain to others the choices we make.

title: 335: June 2; Apocalypse Then and Now (New Testament Week 22)
description: SECRET BIBLE CODE REVEALS THE EXACT DATE OF THE END OF THE WORLD!!

title: 336: June 9, 16; Let this cup pass from me (New Testament Weeks 23-24)
description: Gethsemane. These chapters teach us some of the hardest, most essential lessons life requires. How do we deal with betrayal? How do we have the strength to show up for each other? And most importantly, how do we align what we want with what must be? How do we shift, turn, return, to God’s path?

title: 337: June 23; Even though it be a cross (New Testament Week 25)
description: Jesus’ crucifixion isn’t really about his death… it is about  misunderstanding, humiliation, and the tragic subversion of Jesus’  proclamation that the Kingdom has come near.

title: 338: June 30; Empty Tomb (New Testament Week 26)
description: Have faith in Jesus, even though you haven’t seen him. This is the message of each of the gospels. And Jesus’ message to us is to love each other during this life.

title: 82.1: Cain vs. Enoch; OT Lesson 5 (Core)
description: Containing some of the most sublime verses in LDS scripture, these chapters also present a study in contrasts.

title: 82.2: Cain vs. Enoch; OT Lesson 5 (Study Notes)
description: Part II of the episode discusses Cain and Abel in literary and historical perspective, then introduces some ancient traditions about Enoch

title: 84.1: The Abrahamic Covenant; OT Lesson 7 (Core)
description: In essence, the Abrahamic covenant is about how God uses those who make covenants and live well to bless the lives of all their children. This section introduces Abraham, explores how God works with us in our limitations and weakness, as well as the impact of covenants on our relationship with God and others. Finally, we discuss our responsibility to appreciate our strengths and weaknesses, privileges and limitations and use our blessings to live well and bless the lives of others.

title: 84.2: The Abrahamic Covenant; OT Lesson 7 (Study Notes)
description: This portion of the episode explores:

title: Gospel Doctrine Lesson 1: Introduction to the Doctrine & Covenants and Church History
